STAR-RIS Assisted Over-the-Air Vertical Federated Learning in Multi-Cell Wireless Networks

Xiangyu Zeng∗⁣†‡superscriptXiangyu Zeng∗†absent‡\text{Xiangyu Zeng}^{\ast\dagger\ddagger}, Yijie Mao∗superscriptYijie Mao∗\text{Yijie Mao}^{\ast}, and Yuanming Shi∗superscriptYuanming Shi∗\text{Yuanming Shi}^{\ast} ∗School of Information Science and Technology, ShanghaiTech University, Shanghai 201210, China
†Shanghai Institute of Microsystem and Information Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China
‡University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China
E-mail: {zengxy, maoyj, shiym}@shanghaitech.edu.cn
Abstract

Vertical federated learning (FL) is a critical enabler for distributed artificial intelligence services in the emerging 6G era, as it allows for secure and efficient collaboration of machine learning among a wide range of Internet of Things devices. However, current studies of wireless FL typically consider a single task in a single-cell wireless network, ignoring the impact of inter-cell interference on learning performance. In this paper, we investigate a simultaneous transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS) assisted over-the-air computation based vertical FL system in multi-cell networks, in which a STAR-RIS is deployed at the cell edge to facilitate the completion of different FL tasks in different cells. We establish the convergence of the proposed system through theoretical analysis and introduce the Pareto boundary of the optimality gaps to characterize the trade-off among cells. Based on the analysis, we then jointly design the transmit and receive beamforming as well as the STAR-RIS transmission and reflection coefficient matrices to minimize the sum of the gaps of all cells. To solve the non-convex resource allocation problem, we introduce a successive convex approximation based algorithm. Numerical experiments demonstrate that compared with conventional approaches, the proposed STAR-RIS assisted vertical FL model and the cooperative resource allocation algorithm achieve much lower mean-squared error for both uplink and downlink transmission in multi-cell wireless networks, resulting in improved learning performance for vertical FL.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a machine learning (ML) approach that enables multiple parties to collaboratively train a learning model without revealing their individual data. This is beneficial in a variety of fields where data privacy is a concern, as FL allows parties to maintain control over their own data while still benefiting from the combined knowledge of all parties. In modern wireless Internet of Things (IoT) networks, data is often collected from various types of devices [1]. To facilitate data analysis in such settings, vertical FL, a variation of FL that is designed to address the challenges of training machine learning models on vertically partitioned data silos, is commonly adopted [2, 3, 4, 5, 6].

One major issue that prevents the implementation of (vertical) FL in real-world application is the communication latency. To address this issue, over-the-air computation (AirComp) has been proposed to facilitate fast wireless data aggregation. By utilizing the superposition property of wireless multiple access channels (MAC) to concurrently transmit and aggregate local updates, AirComp significantly reduces communication latency compared to orthogonal transmission. Previous research has explored the use of AirComp in FL, such as the joint design of device selection and beamforming for fast global model aggregation in [5], and the development of a broadband analog aggregation scheme for low latency FL with linear growth of latency reduction ratio in [7].

On the other hand, the coexistence of multiple FL tasks in multi-cell networks has yet to be fully explored. Though the authors in [8] have studied the bandwidth allocation for multiple FL tasks, the system model is limited to a single-cell network and the impact of inter-cell interference on FL performance remains unplumbed. It has been well investigated that reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS), a metasurface composed of reconfigurable passive elements, can modify the propagation environment of wireless signal and reduce multi-cell interference [9]. However, conventional RISs are reflecting only with limited wireless coverage [10]. The recently introduced simultaneous transmitting and reflecting RIS (STAR-RIS), which allows the source and destination to be located at either side of the metasurface, has been recognized as a promising strategy to enhance the coverage of each cell and further reduce inter-cell interference [11]. STAR-RIS is therefore a promising technique to facilitate FL in multi-cell networks. To the best of our knowledge, STAR-RIS assisted vertical FL has not been studied yet.

In this paper, inspired by the benefits of AirComp for global aggregation [12] and the merits of STAR-RIS in multi-cell networks, we fill the research gap and propose a STAR-RIS assisted AirComp-based vertical FL in multi-cell networks, where a STAR-RIS is deployed at the cell edge to assist each cell in completing different FL tasks. Through theoretical analysis, we demonstrate the convergence of our proposed vertical FL process and introduce the Pareto boundary of the gap region to characterize the trade-off performance among multiple cells. This allows us to formulate an optimization problem with the aim of minimizing the sum of error-induced gaps for all cells using the proposed algorithm based on successive convex approximation (SCA). Numerical experiments confirm the validity of our theoretical analysis and show the superiority of our proposed approach.

Since the BS only needs the aggregation of local prediction results, i.e., neither local features nor local models need be uploaded to the BS, which significantly enhances privacy protection. In addition, the communication efficiency is improved since the local prediction result is usually low-dimensional.

II-C Communication Model

In this subsection, the proposed communication model is delineated with a special focus on the STAR-RIS assisted uplink and downlink transmission models.

II-C1 STAR-RIS

The STAR-RIS is a type of RIS that can produce omnidirectional radiation by implementing equivalent electric and magnetic currents in its hardware. It has three protocols for use in wireless networks: energy splitting, mode switching, and time switching. In this article, we focus on the mode-switching protocol, in which each element of the STAR-RIS can operate in either the reflection mode (R mode) or the transmission mode (T mode). Such on-off type of operating protocol is simpler to implement compared to the energy splitting protocol. Specifically, one group consists of Qtsuperscript𝑄𝑡Q^{t} elements operating in the T mode, while the other group contains Qrsuperscript𝑄𝑟Q^{r} elements operating in the R mode, where Qt+Qr=Qsuperscript𝑄𝑡superscript𝑄𝑟𝑄Q^{t}+Q^{r}=Q. Accordingly, the STAR-RIS transmission-coefficient and reflection-coefficient matrices are given by 𝚯t=subscript𝚯𝑡absent\bm{\Theta}_{t}= diag⁡(β1t​ej​θ1t,β2t​ej​θ2t,…,βQt​ej​θQt)diagsuperscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑡superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽2𝑡superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑄𝑡superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑄𝑡\operatorname{diag}\left(\sqrt{\beta_{1}^{t}}e^{j\theta_{1}^{t}},\sqrt{\beta_{2}^{t}}e^{j\theta_{2}^{t}},\ldots,\sqrt{\beta_{Q}^{t}}e^{j\theta_{Q}^{t}}\right) and 𝚯r=diag⁡(β1r​ej​θ1r,β2r​ej​θ2r,…,βQr​ej​θQr)subscript𝚯𝑟diagsuperscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃1𝑟superscriptsubscript𝛽2𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃2𝑟…superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑄𝑟superscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑄𝑟\bm{\Theta}_{r}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\sqrt{\beta_{1}^{r}}e^{j\theta_{1}^{r}},\sqrt{\beta_{2}^{r}}e^{j\theta_{2}^{r}},\ldots,\sqrt{\beta_{Q}^{r}}e^{j\theta_{Q}^{r}}\right), respectively, where βqt,βqr∈{0,1},βqt+βqr=1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑞𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑞𝑟01superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑞𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑞𝑟1\beta_{q}^{t},\beta_{q}^{r}\in\{0,1\},\beta_{q}^{t}+\beta_{q}^{r}=1, and θqt,θqr∈[0,2​π),∀q∈{1,2,…,Q}formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑞𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑞𝑟02𝜋for-all𝑞12…𝑄\theta_{q}^{t},\theta_{q}^{r}\in[0,2\pi),\forall q\in\{1,2,\ldots,Q\}. The M𝑀M cells can be divided into two groups ℳrsubscriptℳ𝑟\mathcal{M}_{r} and ℳtsubscriptℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}_{t}. Specifically, cell m𝑚m is in the reflection dimension with m∈ℳr𝑚subscriptℳ𝑟m\in\mathcal{M}_{r} and in the transmission dimension with m∈ℳt𝑚subscriptℳ𝑡m\in\mathcal{M}_{t}.

Let 𝒉m,k∈ℂN,𝒉kr∈ℂQformulae-sequencesubscript𝒉𝑚𝑘superscriptℂ𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑟superscriptℂ𝑄\bm{h}_{m,k}\in\mathbb{C}^{N},\bm{h}_{k}^{r}\in\mathbb{C}^{Q} and 𝑮m∈ℂQ×Nsubscript𝑮𝑚superscriptℂ𝑄𝑁\bm{G}_{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{Q\times N} denote the equivalent channels from edge device k𝑘k to BS m𝑚m, from edge device k𝑘k to the STAR-RIS, and from the STAR-RIS to BS m𝑚m, respectively. The combined channel from the k𝑘k-th edge device to the BS m𝑚m via the STAR-RIS can be written as

II-C2 Uplink transmission

In the uplink transmission, we assume the devices communicate with the BS via AirComp, which has a wide range of FL applications.

Specifically, we denote 𝒔k=[sk1,sk2,⋯,skL]𝖳∈ℂLsubscript𝒔𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝐿𝖳superscriptℂ𝐿\bm{s}_{k}=[s_{k}^{1},s_{k}^{2},\cdots,s_{k}^{L}]^{\sf T}\in\mathbb{C}^{L} as the local prediction results at device k𝑘k, where the local prediction result of the i𝑖i-th sample ski=𝒘k𝖳​𝒙ki.superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝖳superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑖s_{k}^{i}=\bm{w}_{k}^{\sf T}\bm{x}_{k}^{i}. III Convergence Analysis and Problem Formulation

III-A Convergence Analysis

In previous work [14, 15, 12], the convergence analysis of the AirComp-based vertical FL process in each cell has been established under the following assumptions.

Assumption 1 (α𝛼\alpha-strongly convexity).

The function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is assumed to be α𝛼\alpha-strongly convex on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} with constant α𝛼\alpha, namely, for all 𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

F​(𝒚)≥F​(𝒙)+∇F​(𝒙)𝖳​(𝒚−𝒙)+α2​‖𝒚−𝒙‖22.𝐹𝒚𝐹𝒙∇𝐹superscript𝒙𝖳𝒚𝒙𝛼2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒚𝒙22F(\bm{y})\geq F(\bm{x})+\nabla F(\bm{x})^{\sf T}(\bm{y}-\bm{x})+\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\|_{2}^{2}.
Assumption 2 (β𝛽\beta-smoothness).

The function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is assumed to be β𝛽\beta-smooth on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} with constant β𝛽\beta, namely, for all 𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

F​(𝒚)≤F​(𝒙)+∇F​(𝒙)𝖳​(𝒚−𝒙)+β2​‖𝒚−𝒙‖22.𝐹𝒚𝐹𝒙∇𝐹superscript𝒙𝖳𝒚𝒙𝛽2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒚𝒙22F(\bm{y})\leq F(\bm{x})+\nabla F(\bm{x})^{\sf T}(\bm{y}-\bm{x})+\frac{\beta}{2}\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\|_{2}^{2}.

III-B Problem Formulation

According to Theorem 1, the convergence optimality gap is largely determined by the mean-squared-error (MSE) of both gmsubscript𝑔𝑚g_{m} and Gmsubscript𝐺𝑚G_{m}. However, solely optimizing MSE for each cell through AirComp may result in significant inter-cell interference in the considered multi-cell wireless networks, which can negatively impact the learning performance of other cells. As such, it is necessary to carefully balance the learning performance among various FL tasks in multiple cells through a cooperative design.

We begin by identifying the gap region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, to be the set of tuples (Δ1,Δ2,…,ΔM)subscriptΔ1subscriptΔ2…subscriptΔ𝑀\left(\Delta_{1},\Delta_{2},\ldots,\Delta_{M}\right), which represents the instantaneous errors that cause gaps in all cells, and can be achieved simultaneously under specific downlink and uplink transmission power constraints. The gap region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} can be represented as

𝒢=⋃{(Δ1,Δ2,…,ΔM)|Δm≥Gapm,∀m∈ℳ},𝒢conditional-setsubscriptΔ1subscriptΔ2…subscriptΔ𝑀formulae-sequencesubscriptΔ𝑚subscriptGap𝑚for-all𝑚ℳ\mathcal{G}=\bigcup\{(\Delta_{1},\Delta_{2},\ldots,\Delta_{M})|\Delta_{m}\geq\text{Gap}_{m},\forall m\in\mathcal{M}\}, (14)

where

Gapm=∑k∈𝒦m(Φ1,k​𝔼​[|ℜ⁡{emul}|2]+Φ2,k​𝔼​[|ℜ⁡{e¯kdl}|2]),subscriptGap𝑚subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑚subscriptΦ1𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑚ul2subscriptΦ2𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝑒𝑘dl2\text{Gap}_{m}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{m}}\left(\Phi_{1,k}\mathbb{E}[|\Re\{e_{m}^{\text{ul}}\}|^{2}]+\Phi_{2,k}\mathbb{E}[|\Re\{\bar{e}_{k}^{\text{dl}}\}|^{2}]\right), (15)
𝔼​[|ℜ⁡{emul}|2]=∑l≠m,j∈𝒦lηl​|𝒓m𝖧​𝒉¯m,j|2ηm​|𝒓l𝖧​𝒉¯l,j|2+‖𝒓m‖2​σul2ηm,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑚ul2subscriptformulae-sequence𝑙𝑚𝑗subscript𝒦𝑙subscript𝜂𝑙superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒓𝑚𝖧subscript¯𝒉𝑚𝑗2subscript𝜂𝑚superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒓𝑙𝖧subscript¯𝒉𝑙𝑗2superscriptnormsubscript𝒓𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝜎ul2subscript𝜂𝑚\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[|\Re\{e_{m}^{\text{ul}}\}|^{2}]=\sum_{l\neq m,j\in\mathcal{K}_{l}}\frac{\eta_{l}|\bm{r}_{m}^{\sf H}\bar{\bm{h}}_{m,j}|^{2}}{\eta_{m}|\bm{r}_{l}^{\sf H}\bar{\bm{h}}_{l,j}|^{2}}+\frac{\|\bm{r}_{m}\|^{2}\sigma_{\text{ul}}^{2}}{\eta_{m}}, (16)
𝔼​[|ℜ⁡{e¯kdl}|2]=∑l≠m|𝒉¯l,k𝖧​𝒕l|2+(σdl)2|𝒉¯m,k𝖧​𝒕m|2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝑒𝑘dl2subscript𝑙𝑚superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒉𝑙𝑘𝖧subscript𝒕𝑙2superscriptsuperscript𝜎dl2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒉𝑚𝑘𝖧subscript𝒕𝑚2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[|\Re\{\bar{e}_{k}^{\text{dl}}\}|^{2}]=\frac{\sum_{l\neq m}|\bar{\bm{h}}_{l,k}^{\sf H}\bm{t}_{l}|^{2}+(\sigma^{\text{dl}})^{2}}{\left|\bar{\bm{h}}_{m,k}^{\sf H}\bm{t}_{m}\right|^{2}}.

As previously stated, in order to decrease the error-induced gap in one cell, the gaps of other cells maybe increased. In light of this, our objective is to find a suitable solution that allows us to achieve the Pareto boundary of the gap region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, so as to balance the performance of learning among multiple cells. In this context, the Pareto optimality of a tuple is described as follows[16].

Here, we leverage the profiling technique [17] to characterize the Pareto boundary by coordinating all BSs to minimize the sum of Gap of all cells. Specifically, let κ=[κ1,κ2,…,κM]𝜅subscript𝜅1subscript𝜅2…subscript𝜅𝑀\kappa=\left[\kappa_{1},\kappa_{2},\ldots,\kappa_{M}\right] denote a given profiling vector, which satisfies κm≥0,∀m∈ℳformulae-sequencesubscript𝜅𝑚0for-all𝑚ℳ\kappa_{m}\geq 0,\forall m\in\mathcal{M}, and ∑m∈ℳκm=subscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝜅𝑚absent\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\kappa_{m}= 1. The gap tuple on Pareto boundary can be obtained by solving the following problem

minimizeζ,{𝒓m},{𝒕m},𝚯t,𝚯r𝜁subscript𝒓𝑚subscript𝒕𝑚subscript𝚯𝑡subscript𝚯𝑟minimize\displaystyle\underset{\zeta,\{\bm{r}_{m}\},\{\bm{t}_{m}\},\bm{\Theta}_{t},\bm{\Theta}_{r}}{\operatorname{minimize}}\quad ζ𝜁\displaystyle\zeta (17a)
s.t. Gapm≤κm​ζ,∀m∈ℳformulae-sequencesubscriptGap𝑚subscript𝜅𝑚𝜁for-all𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\text{Gap}_{m}\leq\kappa_{m}\zeta,\forall m\in\mathcal{M} (17b)
ζ≥0,𝜁0\displaystyle\zeta\geq 0, (17c)

where ζ𝜁\zeta denotes the sum of the gaps of all cells. Thus, the gap tuple can be represented as (Δ1,Δ2,…,ΔM)=(κ1​ζ,κ2​ζ,…,κM​ζ)subscriptΔ1subscriptΔ2…subscriptΔ𝑀subscript𝜅1𝜁subscript𝜅2𝜁…subscript𝜅𝑀𝜁\left(\Delta_{1},\Delta_{2},\ldots,\Delta_{M}\right)=\left(\kappa_{1}\zeta,\kappa_{2}\zeta,\ldots,\kappa_{M}\zeta\right), where a smaller value of κmsubscript𝜅𝑚\kappa_{m} implies a more stringent requirement for the gap of cell m𝑚m.

Denote ζ=ζu​l+ζd​l𝜁superscript𝜁𝑢𝑙superscript𝜁𝑑𝑙\zeta=\zeta^{ul}+\zeta^{dl}, where ζu​lsuperscript𝜁𝑢𝑙\zeta^{ul} and ζd​lsuperscript𝜁𝑑𝑙\zeta^{dl} are used to quantify the sum of instantaneous error-induced gaps generated by uplink and downlink transmissions, respectively. Hence, we rewrite problem (17) as

minimizeζu​l,ζd​l,{𝒓m},{𝒕m},𝚯t,𝚯rsuperscript𝜁𝑢𝑙superscript𝜁𝑑𝑙subscript𝒓𝑚subscript𝒕𝑚subscript𝚯𝑡subscript𝚯𝑟minimize\displaystyle\underset{\zeta^{ul},\zeta^{dl},\{\bm{r}_{m}\},\{\bm{t}_{m}\},\bm{\Theta}_{t},\bm{\Theta}_{r}}{\operatorname{minimize}}\quad ζu​l+ζd​lsuperscript𝜁𝑢𝑙superscript𝜁𝑑𝑙\displaystyle\zeta^{ul}+\zeta^{dl} (18a)
s.t. Gapmu​l≤κm​ζu​l,∀m∈ℳformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptGap𝑚𝑢𝑙subscript𝜅𝑚superscript𝜁𝑢𝑙for-all𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\text{Gap}_{m}^{ul}\leq\kappa_{m}\zeta^{ul},\forall m\in\mathcal{M} (18b)
Gapmd​l≤κm​ζd​l,∀m∈ℳformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptGap𝑚𝑑𝑙subscript𝜅𝑚superscript𝜁𝑑𝑙for-all𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\text{Gap}_{m}^{dl}\leq\kappa_{m}\zeta^{dl},\forall m\in\mathcal{M} (18c)
ζu​l≥0superscript𝜁𝑢𝑙0\displaystyle\zeta^{ul}\geq 0 (18d)
ζd​l≥0.superscript𝜁𝑑𝑙0\displaystyle\zeta^{dl}\geq 0. (18e)

The downlink and uplink transmissions can be decoupled in problem (18), which allows us to separately optimize the downlink and uplink transmission resources.

IV optimization framework

In this section, we specify the optimization framework for solving the uplink and downlink optimization problems, respectively.

and

And we can observe that the above problem turns out to be highly intractable due to the non-convexity of multiplication between variables 𝒒𝒒\bm{q} and 𝚯u​lsuperscript𝚯𝑢𝑙\bm{\Theta}^{ul}. Hence, a classical alternative optimization algorithm can be used to solve it.

V Simulation Results

In this section, we conduct extensive numerical experiments to evaluate the performance of the proposed SCA algorithm for the STAR-RIS assisted AirComp-based vertical FL system in multi-cell wireless network.

We consider a STAR-RIS assisted two-cell wireless vertical FL network in a two-dimensional space, where the coordinates of the BSs are (0​m,0​m)0m0m(0\text{m},0\text{m}) and (40​m,0​m)40m0m(40\text{m},0\text{m}), the STAR-RIS is deployed at the edge of two cells, i.e., (20​m,0​m)20m0m(20\text{m},0\text{m}). And the devices in each cell are uniformly located within a circular region centered at their corresponding BS with radius 202020 meters. All channel coefficients are modeled as

𝒉=ρ−α/2​(β1+β​𝒉LoS+11+β​𝒉NLoS)𝒉superscript𝜌𝛼2𝛽1𝛽subscript𝒉LoS11𝛽subscript𝒉NLoS\bm{h}=\rho^{-\alpha/2}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\beta}{1+\beta}}\bm{h}_{\mathrm{LoS}}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\beta}}\bm{h}_{\mathrm{NLoS}}\right) (28)

and vary independently over different rounds, where ρ𝜌\rho denotes the distance between the transmitter and the receiver, α=2.5𝛼2.5\alpha=2.5 denotes the pathloss exponent, β=5​dB𝛽5dB\beta=5\mathrm{\leavevmode\nobreak\ dB} represents the Rician factor, 𝒉LoS subscript𝒉LoS \bm{h}_{\text{LoS }} denotes the line-of-sight (LoS)LoS(\mathrm{LoS}) component, and 𝒉NLoSsubscript𝒉NLoS\bm{h}_{\mathrm{NLoS}} denotes the non-line-of-sight (NLoS) exponent. In addition, the noise power are set to (σul)2=(σdl)2=−10​d​B​msuperscriptsuperscript𝜎ul2superscriptsuperscript𝜎dl210dBm\left(\sigma^{\mathrm{ul}}\right)^{2}=\left(\sigma^{\mathrm{dl}}\right)^{2}=-10\mathrm{dBm}. All simulation results in the following are obtained by averaging over 100 experiments.

We first evaluate the performance of uplink aggregation using AirComp and downlink dissemination error by considering the MSE as the metric. As shown in Fig. 1, the MSE decreases as the number of STAR-RIS elements increases for both downlink and uplink transmission, indicating that STAR-RIS can effectively enhance the signal transmission quality, particularly when it has a large number of elements.

We further evaluate the performance of our proposed STAR-RIS assisted vertical FL system, where Km=4subscript𝐾𝑚4K_{m}=4 devices in each cell cooperatively train a regularized logistic regression model. The number of antennas at each BS is N=8𝑁8N=8, and the number of elements at STAR-RIS is Q=10𝑄10Q=10. We simulate the image classification task on Fashion-MNIST dataset [18]. And we assume that each cell perform a different binary classification task for simplify (0-1 in cell 1, 2-3 in cell 2). The traditional binary cross-entropy loss function is given as

F​(𝒘)=−1L​∑i=1L[yi​(𝒘​𝒙i)−ln⁡(1+exp⁡(𝒘​𝒙i))].𝐹𝒘1𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿delimited-[]superscript𝑦𝑖𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖1𝒘superscript𝒙𝑖F(\bm{w})=-\frac{1}{L}\sum_{i=1}^{L}\left[y^{i}\left(\bm{wx}^{i}\right)-\ln\left(1+\exp(\bm{wx}^{i})\right)\right].

The learning rate μ(t)superscript𝜇𝑡\mu^{(t)} is set to 0.010.010.01.

We consider the noiseless case as the performance upper bound. Fig. 2 shows that our proposed STAR-RIS assisted system converges quickly and achieves 96%percent9696\% testing accuracy in inference, which is far ahead compared with the other two cases. And it is even close to the performance upper bound.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a STAR-RIS assisted AirComp-based vertical FL system in multi-cell networks. To be specific, a STAR-RIS is deployed at the cell edge to facilitate the completion of different FL tasks by each cell. The Pareto boundary of the gap region is introduced to characterize the trade-off of learning performance among cells. We then formulate an optimization problem to minimize the sum of error-induced gaps across all cells, which is then solved by SCA-based algorithms. Our simulation results demonstrate that the proposed STAR-RIS assisted system can significantly improve the learning performance in both training and inference phases thanks to its powerful capability of reducing the transmission errors.
